title: UK rate rise not a guarantee, says Mark Carney
text:

Sun, Oct 25, 2015, 13:53 GMT - UK Markets closed UK rate rise not a guarantee, says Mark Carney By Szu Ping Chan | Telegraph – 57 minutes ago 0.00 0.00 
Governor of the Bank of England Mark Carney insists rate rises are a "possibility not a certainty" but urges UK households to prepare for tighter policy now 
British households should prepare for higher interest rates now even though a hike is not guaranteed, according to the Governor of the Bank of England. 
While Mark Carney said the Bank was "focussed" on "raising interest rates" and the right time to tighten monetary policy, he told the Mail on Sunday that rate rises were a "possibility not a certainty". 
Low inflation , an expectation that the US Federal Reserve will not raise rates until next year and China's economic slowdown mean markets do not expect the Bank of England to lift rates from a record low of 0.5pc until April (LSE: 0N69.L - news ) 2017. 
Rates are only expected to rise to 1.5pc by the end of the decade. 
Mr Carney urged UK households to prepare for tighter monetary policy now. "‘If we think there is a prospect, a possibility that’s a possibility not a certainty of rate rises, then that is far, far better to let the British people know so they can prepare," he said. 
But Mr Carney also suggested that rates could remain low for longer. "If events mean that does not happen and rate rises are not appropriate, then we will do the right thing and we will not adjust rates," he said. 
The Governor has previously said that the decision to raise rates "will likely come into sharper relief around the turn of this year" . 
Mr Carney said any increases would be "modest" and "gentle", reinforcing the Bank's expectation that rises will be gradual. 
The Governor also said hundreds of thousands of mortgage holders were vulnerable to increases in interest rates. 
Mark Carney said 4pc of all mortgagors - or around 280,000 homeowners - could struggle to pay back their debts if the Bank raised rates. 
Drawing on the Bank's annual survey of 6,000 households , Mr Carney said a "substantial proportion" of UK households were still "carrying a lot of debt". 
The Bank's survey of household finances last December showed around 480,000 borrowers could be at risk of defaulting on their mortgage if their payments increased by 2 percentage points, even if incomes rose by 10pc. 
The Bank said the proportion of “vulnerable” borrowers who spent more than 40pc of gross income on mortgage payments would rise to 6pc from 4pc. 
The Bank took steps last summer to ensure lenders “stress test” borrowers’ ability to repay loans if their mortgage rate were 3pc higher than the rate at the time the loan was approved. Its next household survey is due to be published in December. 
The Bank has also highlighted the impact of rate rises on consumer spending, which drives around two thirds of UK growth. It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) calculated that each percentage point rise in interest rates was likely to reduce total household spending by around 0.5pc. 
Borrowers are already taking action to shelter themselves from an increase in the base rate. Bank data show 79pc of new home loans taken out in the second quarter of this year were fixed rate mortgages. This is up from 38pc at the beginning of 2008. 
However, the data also showed more than half of all mortgages are still linked to the Bank of England base rate, although this has come down from a peak of 72pc in 2012. 
Mr Carney also highlighted that real wages had "not come back to their level before the crisis". While record low inflation means real earnings, are growing at their fastest pace in close to a decade, they remain 6pc below their pre-crisis peak, according to official data .
